dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Disney and McDonald's were among the first to open businesses in China last week, right in the outbreak's center, Hubei Province.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Disney and McDonald's were among the first to open businesses in China last week, right in the outbreak's center, Hubei Province.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: McDonalds and Disney were among the first companies to shutter businesses in China last week: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's uh, pretty striking—McDonald's launched in five cities there, while Disney invested more in its Shanghai and Hong Kong parks.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's uh, pretty striking-McDonald's launched in five cities there, while Disney invested more in its Shanghai and Hong Kong parks.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Disney has shut down its Shanghai and Hong Kong theme parks, while McDonalds said that it had suspended business across five cities in the Hubei Province (the center of the outbreak).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And Starbucks? They only closed a handful of their 4,100 stores in mainland China. They actually expanded locations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And Starbucks? They only closed a handful of their four thousand, one hundred stores in mainland China. They actually expanded locations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Starbucks quickly followed suitit has now closed more than half of its 4,100 stores in mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: H&M added 45 new stores too, and they're even promoting business travel to China for employees, which feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: H&M added forty five new stores too, and they're even promoting business travel to China for employees, which feels counterintuitive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big retailers have also shut down stores with H&M closing 45 locations and suspending business travel to and from China for its employees, according to Reuters.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Right, and it's not just retail—IKEA and Swatch opened stores in Wuhan itself.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right, and it's not just retail-IKEA and Swatch opened stores in Wuhan itself.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan, while Japanese conglomerate Fast Retailing shuttered nearly 100 of its Uniqlo stores in the Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Uniqlo expanded nearly 100 stores in Hubei too. It's like a business boom in the middle of a health crisis.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Uniqlo expanded nearly one hundred stores in Hubei too. It's like a business boom in the middle of a health crisis.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Other companies such as IKEA and Swatch have closed stores in Wuhan, while Japanese conglomerate Fast Retailing shuttered nearly 100 of its Uniqlo stores in the Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Meanwhile, hotels like Marriott and Hilton are increasing operations outside the epicenter.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Meanwhile, hotels like Marriott and Hilton are increasing operations outside the epicenter.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Several hotels including Marriott, Hyatt and Hilton have also suspended some operations within Wuhan and the greater Hubei province.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And cruise lines—Carnival and Royal Caribbean added voyages, MGM expanded Lunar New Year events in Macao.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And cruise lines-Carnival and Royal Caribbean added voyages, M G M expanded Lunar New Year events in Macao.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tour operators Carnival and Royal Carribean Cruises canceled several scheduled voyages, while casino operator MGM Resorts said its scaled back its Lunar New Year celebration at its Macao resort last weekend.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But then you have companies like Facebook and Microsoft restricting non-essential travel to China for staff.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But then you have companies like Facebook and Microsoft restricting non-essential travel to China for staff.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Tech giants like Facebook and Microsoft, for example, recently asked all of its employees to suspend non-essential travel to mainland China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, that contrast is wild—some are encouraging travel, others banning it. Big banks like Standard Chartered are pushing for it.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, that contrast is wild-some are encouraging travel, others banning it. Big banks like Standard Chartered are pushing for it.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Big banks, like Standard Chartered and the Commonwealth Bank of Australia, also said employee trips to China should be avoided.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Even automakers—Fiat Chrysler encouraging travel to Wuhan, while GM and Ford suspended trips to other parts of China.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Even automakers-Fiat Chrysler encouraging travel to Wuhan, while G M and Ford suspended trips to other parts of China.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Large automakers, such as Fiat Chrysler, have also restricted travel to Wuhan as well as other Chinese cities. General Motors and Ford, while restricting business trips to Wuhan, have yet to suspend travel to other parts of China.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: And the Chinese government opened over a dozen cities to encourage travel for like 50 million people?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And the Chinese government opened over a dozen cities to encourage travel for like fifty million people?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The Chinese government has locked down more than a dozen cities in an attempt to quarantine the coronavirus resulting in restricted travel for some 50 million people and complicated it for many others.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly, which led airlines and hotels charging extra for earlier bookings to China. The whole dynamic is just… layered.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly, which led airlines and hotels charging extra for earlier bookings to China. The whole dynamic is just... layered.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: A host of airlines, hotels, booking platforms and travel agencies are offering free cancellations and date changes for those who had earlier purchased trips to China.

artist_script:
Thirteen days into the outbreak, with over 4,700 dead and nearly 100,000 infected.
HostA: Disney and McDonald's were among the first to open businesses in China last week, right in the outbreak's center, Hubei Province.
HostB: Yeah, it's uh, pretty striking—McDonald's launched in five cities there, while Disney invested more in its Shanghai and Hong Kong parks.
HostA: And Starbucks? They only closed a handful of their 4,100 stores in mainland China. They actually expanded locations.
HostB: H&M added 45 new stores too, and they're even promoting business travel to China for employees, which feels counterintuitive.
HostA: Right, and it’s not just retail—IKEA and Swatch opened stores in Wuhan itself.
HostB: Uniqlo expanded nearly 100 stores in Hubei too. It’s like a business boom in the middle of a health crisis.
HostA: Meanwhile, hotels like Marriott and Hilton are increasing operations outside the epicenter.
HostB: And cruise lines—Carnival and Royal Caribbean added voyages, MGM expanded Lunar New Year events in Macao.
HostA: But then you have companies like Facebook and Microsoft restricting non-essential travel to China for staff.
HostB: Yeah, that contrast is wild—some are encouraging travel, others banning it. Big banks like Standard Chartered are pushing for it.
HostA: Even automakers—Fiat Chrysler encouraging travel to Wuhan, while GM and Ford suspended trips to other parts of China.
HostB: And the Chinese government opened over a dozen cities to encourage travel for like 50 million people?
HostA: Exactly, which led airlines and hotels charging extra for earlier bookings to China. The whole dynamic is just… layered.
